ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a historical understanding of the field of American Studies and its contemporary formations. From transatlantic, transpacific, hemispheric, archipelagic, indigenous places, borders, etc. all these frameworks helped me better understand the field and my potential entry points for intervention. I also practiced public speaking through class presentations.
An understanding of the field of American Studies, multiple methodological approaches to geographical frameworks, feminist and literature studies.

I learned so much in this class, and I'm still ruminating on everything, but I think most importantly I was exposed to the work of scholars who were thinking deeply and differently about ways of framing American studies
Many dimensions of a global American Studies

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More time spent on individual readings would have helped focus discussion at times and would allow for more in depth engagement with a text
Strengths: Great readings and discussion! Weaknesses: Sometimes too much reading each week to really be able to engage meaningfully with each one.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to students in American Studies because it fills the gaps that were present in my American Scholars class.
Absolutely. Great overview and discussion, and prof took time to organise and lead class
Yes, absolutely. A fundamental course for any American Studies student
